author: By Patti Davis and Jillian Weinberger
title: Matthew Perry, Loneliness and My Own Addiction
description: Patti Davis reflects on what she sees as the root of addiction.
content: In a memoir published a year ago, Matthew Perry wrote about his longtime struggle with drugs and alcohol. His recent death prompted the author Patti Davis to reflect on her own experience with addiction. In this audio essay, Davis explains why she believes loneliness is at the center of addiction and how Perry’s life story reflects that.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Cacciola
title: To Train for One Marathon, He Runs 7 Every Week
description: Cameron Levins, among the favorites to win the New York City Marathon, runs about 180 miles a week, or nearly 26 miles a day on average.
content: Long before he emerged as one of the best men’s marathoners in the world, Cameron Levins was just trying to run faster than his friend next door.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lyna Bentahar
title: Rothko, in Pain and Glory
description: An illuminating new museum retrospective. Plus, a new podcast for kids and the latest from the Middle East.
content: You may recognize Mark Rothko’s paintings, even if you can’t recall the artist’s name: tall canvases of bold, floating blocks of color. Their titles, such as “No. 13,” “Red on Maroon,” even “Untitled,” are just as abstract as the paintings themselves.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reuters
title: Berkshire Stung by Losses in Its Stock Holdings
description: The conglomerate’s cash stake swelled to a record $157.2 billion in the third quarter even as it posted $23.5 billion in losses from investments.
content: Berkshire Hathaway, the conglomerate run by Warren Buffett, posted its first overall quarterly loss in a year on Saturday on the falling prices of Apple and other stocks it owns, though it said improvement in its insurance operations boosted operating profit to a record.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Even in War, Death of a ‘Friends’ Star Is Painful for Ukrainians
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, November 4, 2023.
content: “We need to remember those dying here in Ukraine daily, but maybe also those who inspire us.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma G. Fitzsimmons and Michael Rothfeld
title: Did Fake Donors Give the Mayor Real Money? The F.B.I. Wants to Know.
description: A search at the home of Mayor Eric Adams’s fund-raising chief sought information about a so-called straw donor scheme.
content: It is a type of scheme that took down New York’s lieutenant governor last year, and sank the 2013 mayoral campaign of a top Democratic contender: the use of so-called straw donors to funnel illegal contributions to candidates from secret sources.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Robbin Bain, Pageant Winner and ‘Today Girl,’ Is Dead at 87
description: After winning the annual Miss Rheingold beauty contest, in which millions voted, she covered fashion and beauty for the popular morning show.
content: Robbin Mele Gaudieri, who, as Robbin Bain, embodied traditional women’s roles as the winner of a beauty contest designed to promote beer in 1959 and later as the “Today Girl,” handling fashion and beauty segments, on the popular NBC-TV morning show, died on Oct. 21 in Southampton, N.Y., on Long Island. She was 87.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Lerer
title: Obama Urges Americans to Take in ‘Whole Truth’ of Israel-Gaza War
description: The former president said everyone was “complicit to some degree” in the current bloodshed and acknowledged the points of view on both sides of the conflict.
content: Barack Obama offered a complex analysis of the conflict between Israel and Gaza, telling thousands of former aides that they were all “complicit to some degree” in the current bloodshed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Bozzone
title: How a D.J. and Music Supervisor Spends Her Sundays
description: Alix Brown immerses herself in records, cinema and books before preparing a favorite Italian dinner.
content: About a decade ago, Alix Brown, a canny and kittenish 39-year-old bassist from Atlanta, parlayed her obsession with obscure music and her playful ’60s “It-girl” persona into a career as a D.J. She spins at special events for fashion labels like Chanel, Fendi and Armani and has honed the signature sound for the Soho Grand Hotel and the Roxy Hotel in New York.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Kodé
title: Seeking a Home for His Parents, a Son Built a Community
description: Priya Living, a senior living company that is steeped in Indian culture, began with a small footprint in California and now has expansion plans in the U.S. and India.
content: When Arun Paul’s parents were in their 70s, he began searching for a duplex in his neighborhood in the Bay Area where they could live. The plan was that Mr. Paul would be close by, but his parents would also share the duplex with their friends, another older couple.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: SATURDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jordyn Holman
title: U.S. Retailers Say an Old Trade Law Puts Them at a Disadvantage
description: A nearly century-old rule exempts many packages from foreign e-commerce companies like Shein and Temu from U.S. customs fees. American trade groups want it changed.
content: American retailers have faced an existential crisis since e-commerce disrupted the industry’s traditional business models. But their latest threat, a group of retailers and policymakers say, is coming from a nearly century-old trade rule that has given their e-commerce rivals — many of them founded in China — an unfair advantage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Cottle
title: Glenn Youngkin and the Lost Republican Art of Winning
description: Can Virginia’s governor sell the G.O.P. on a path other than MAGA?
content: It’s a perfect fall weekend in Virginia horse country, about two weeks before Election Day, and the American Legion hall in Middleburg is decked out for a rally featuring Gov. Glenn Youngkin, who is not on the ballot but is stumping hard for his fellow Republicans. His name is everywhere: on a bright blue backdrop behind the stage, on the swag in the front room, on the side of a bus out front with the slogan “Strengthening the Spirit of Virginia Together.” The bus is a high-end prop for Mr. Youngkin’s “Secure Your Vote” tour, which has him crisscrossing the state to promote early voting. His attempt to reverse Republican mistrust of early and absentee voting is one way the governor stands apart from the leader of his party, Donald Trump. But it is not the only way.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Eavis, Matthew Haag and Julie Creswell
title: WeWork Bankruptcy Would Deal Another Blow to Ailing N.Y. Office Market
description: The fallout would be particularly hard for landlords already struggling with piling debt and companies scaling back their office footprint.
content: For years, landlords around the world clamored to get WeWork into their office buildings, a love affair that made the co-working company the largest corporate tenant in New York and London.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Lerer and Shane Goldmacher
title: Will Abortion Dominate the 2024 Elections? Tuesday Will Offer Clues.
description: Elections in Kentucky, Ohio and Virginia will give an early preview of how abortion will shape the political landscape in 2024, and the effectiveness of both parties’ approaches.
content: Abortion has emerged as a defining fault line of this year’s elections, with consequential contests in several states on Tuesday offering fresh tests of the issue’s political potency nearly 18 months after the Supreme Court ended a federal right to an abortion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eve Washington, Josh Katz and Tom Giratikanon
title: Top 10 Hardest and Easiest Spelling Bee Words, Oct. 28-Nov. 3
description: Some are so tough that you probably shouldn’t stew over them.
content: Note: If you plan to play Spelling Bee’s Past Puzzles from the last week, this list may contain spoilers.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Nov. 4, 2023
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Nov. 4, 2023.
content: An article on Thursday about the House’s vote to block a censure of Representative Rashida Tlaib of Michigan misstated the date of a pro-Palestinian protest that Ms. Tlaib participated in. It was Oct. 18, not Oct. 8.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Abrams
title: A Story About Tupac I Never Expected to Write
description: His music was transcendent. His death was shocking. Suddenly, grand jury testimony has offered an account of what happened the night Tupac Shakur was killed.
content: I had just finished writing an article on Tupac Shakur’s enduring legacy and raced to get my youngest son to soccer practice when one of my editors, Michael Cooper, sent me an email containing a trove of grand jury testimony relating to his long-unsolved murder.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Double Talk
description: Need a hand with this Rich Katz construction? Listen carefully …
content: Jump to: Tricky Clues | Today’s Theme
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane
title: How Louisiana Democrats Lost Before a Ballot Was Cast
description: Even before the Nov. 18 election, some liberals are pushing the state party to confront its internal divisions and paltry fund-raising.
content: Before a single ballot was cast, Louisiana Democrats knew they couldn’t win control of the State Legislature this year. It was mathematically impossible, because a lack of candidates meant they were not even contesting the majority of districts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Damien Cave
title: Why China and Australia Are Reconciling. Sort of.
description: Both sides have been cautious in the run-up to Prime Minister Anthony Albanese’s trip to Beijing, avoiding terms like “reset” in favor of “stabilization.”
content: Since 2017, Australia has played David to China’s Goliath: rejecting Chinese pressure to adopt Huawei technology, calling out Chinese political interference, and demanding an inquiry into Covid-19’s origins, even as Beijing blocked Australian imports ranging from coal to wine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalie Alcoba
title: The New Enemies of Argentina’s Far Right: Swifties and the BTS Army
description: Javier Milei wants to be Argentina’s next president. But first he must get around legions of angry Taylor Swift and BTS fans.
content: Javier Milei, a far-right libertarian economist, has stayed aloft in Argentina’s presidential campaign on the wings of the youth vote.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Entous, Eric Schmitt and Julian E. Barnes
title: U.S. Officials Outline Steps to Israel to Reduce Civilian Casualties
description: The measures include using smaller bombs against Hamas, U.S. officials said.
content: U.S. officials said they have privately outlined several steps to Israel to reduce civilian casualties in its military campaign in the Gaza Strip, including using smaller bombs, when going after Hamas leaders and infrastructure.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Lashbrook
title: In ‘Cross-Stitch,’ a Grief-Driven Reflection on Young Womanhood
description: In her searching new novel, Jazmina Barrera threads together loss, needlework and the hypnotic coming-of-age tale of three Mexican teenagers.
content: Needlework is often depicted as a peaceful activity: feminine, unthreatening, decorative. Yet in Jazmina Barrera’s understated and lovely debut novel, “Cross-Stitch,” translated from the Spanish by Christina MacSweeney, embroidery is revealed to be as quietly brutal as young womanhood, despite the shroud of innocence society often places over both.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Healy
title: Phoenix Encampment Is Gone, but the City’s Homeless Crisis Persists
description: The city was under a court order to dismantle “the Zone,” a sprawling downtown homeless encampment, by Saturday.
content: The tents and campfires were gone. The sidewalks where people had built makeshift shelters from wood pallets and blue tarps were empty. On Friday, all that was left of “the Zone,” a sprawling homeless camp in downtown Phoenix, were discarded clothes, trash and questions about what comes next.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jazmine Ulloa
title: Haley, Pledging to ‘Close’ the Border, Is Asked: What About Migrants Who Are Already Here?
description: Tough promises on immigration from Nikki Haley and her rivals for the Republican nomination face logistical and legal barriers.
content: On the national debate stage, in interviews and at town halls, the message on immigration from every top Republican in the 2024 presidential race has resounded clearly: It is time to shut down the nation’s southern border.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caroline Weber
title: The Culture of Protest That Got the Revolution Going in France
description: In “The Revolutionary Temper,” the historian Robert Darnton immerses readers in the world of the everyday Parisians who would help topple the monarchy of Louis XVI.
content: This year, for the better part of winter, spring and summer, people in France engaged in a proud national tradition: mass demonstration. Protesters demanded a reversal of a government measure to raise the country’s retirement age from 62 to 64. At issue was not only a policy but a perception. President Emmanuel Macron had ignored the wishes of his electorate. Leaflets and placards showed Macron’s face superimposed onto a portrait of Louis XVI, the king overthrown by French revolutionaries in September 1792 and beheaded four months later. “Louis XVI, Louis XVI, on t’a décapité,” one ubiquitous chant warned; “Macron, Macron, on peut recommencer.” Translation: Louis XVI, Louis XVI, we decapitated you; Macron, Macron, we can get you, too.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Salman Masood
title: Militant Attack on Air Base Is Latest Episode to Unnerve Pakistan
description: Though it was repelled, the incident is part of a worrying trend of increased assaults on military targets and a rise in extremist violence more generally.
content: The Pakistani military said it had successfully repelled an attack by militants on an air base in central Pakistan on Saturday. But the episode, which came just after another brazen assault on the military, has renewed concerns about the precarious security situation in the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: Remembering Riopelle, the First Canadian Modern Artist Recognized by the World
description: A series of events marking the centennial of the artist’s birth includes a major retrospective at the National Gallery of Canada.
content: He remains the only Canadian artist who is commonly referred to only by his family name and the first to have created a work that sold for more than $1 million, and his fame transcended Canada’s linguistic divide. Now, the centennial of Jean Paul Riopelle’s birth is being marked with a wide array of events.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: A Snapshot of Support for Palestinians Across America
description: Marches in Washington, D.C., Ohio, Utah and California, with tens of thousands of protesters, reflect the many different groups calling for a cease-fire and lifting of the siege in Gaza.
content: Bearing flags and united in fury, tens of thousands of demonstrators crowded the streets of American cities on Saturday to denounce the scope and scale of Israel’s military campaign in Gaza in response to last month’s terrorist assault by Hamas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Kristof and William Keo
title: Losing Hope in the West Bank
description: Forty-one years after I befriended two Palestinian university students, I met up with them again to talk about their lives.
content: When I was a law student backpacking through the Middle East in 1982, I met two Palestinian university students on a local bus in the West Bank. We got to chatting and they invited me to their homes, so I jumped off the bus and spent a day with them in the jumbled alleys of the densely populated Dheisheh Refugee Camp.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracey Tully
title: Failed Wind Deal and Abortion Rights Loom Over Tight Races in New Jersey
description: Despite being outnumbered by nearly a million voters, Republicans hope to cut into Democratic majorities in the state Legislature on Election Day.
content: The news landed like a bombshell a week before New Jersey’s pivotal legislative races: Orsted, a Danish company that had been hired to build two wind farms off the South Jersey coast, was abruptly abandoning the project.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: The Weekender
description: A doctor who tracks Nazi loot. Also: a trip to a Hindu goddess festival, and Kim Kardashian on the future of Skims.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sui-Lee Wee and Ezra Acayan
title: ‘Just Like Medicine’: A New Push for Divorce in a Nation Where It’s Illegal
description: A campaign in the Philippines that frames divorce as a basic human right is gaining momentum, despite systemic and religious barriers.
content: Nearly 15 years ago, Mary Nepomuceno separated from her husband. She remains in limbo because divorce — and the possibility of a new marriage and a clean slate in life — is forbidden by her country’s laws.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: Why Liberal Academia Needs Republican Friends
description: Universities should use the levers of politics and money to rescue the humanities, not destroy them.
content: Here are a few snapshots from higher education in America:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael J. de la Merced and Jordyn Holman
title: How the Real Estate Broker Business Could Change
description: Industry experts say a federal jury ruling this week against the National Association of Realtors and large brokerages makes the current commission model likely to change.
content: A federal jury dealt the biggest blow to the American home-buying industry in perhaps a century this week when it found that the powerful National Association of Realtors and several large brokerages had conspired to keep agent commissions artificially high.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: Nuclear Talks With China Are Essential and Long Overdue
description: After months of tense relations between the U.S. and China, there is a welcome sign of better communication.
content: After months of troubled relations, and then some tentative steps to bridge the gap between the United States and China, there is one glaring omission: American and Chinese military leaders still don’t communicate with one another directly. That’s important because those lines of communication are the best way to avoid the kind of misunderstandings or overreactions that can lead to actual conflict. That’s why it’s encouraging that the countries plan to meet on Monday to discuss arms control.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Holpuch
title: Teacher Shot by 6-Year-Old Student Can Sue School District, Judge Rules
description: Abigail Zwerner was teaching at Richneck Elementary School in Newport News, Va., when a boy shot her in January.
content: An elementary school teacher who was shot by her 6-year-old student in a classroom in Virginia can move forward with a $40 million lawsuit against the school district, a judge ruled on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Molly Young
title: A Scholarly Scoundrel and a Monkish Detective
description: Our critic recommends “Hermit of Peking,” by Hugh Trevor-Roper, and “A Morbid Taste for Bones,” by Ellis Peters.
content: Dear readers,
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear
title: Hamas put wounded fighters on departure lists, delaying efforts to evacuate foreigners, a U.S. official says.
description: People holding dual, U.S. or other foreign citizenship had been unable to cross the Gaza border into Egypt for weeks.
content: A Biden administration official said on Friday that efforts to get Americans and other foreign nationals out of Gaza, a process that began on Wednesday, had been held up by a Hamas attempt to get its own wounded fighters included among those to be escorted into Egypt through the Rafah gate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Orlando Mayorquin
title: Hamburg Airport Closed After Armed Man Drives Onto Tarmac, Prompting Standoff
description: The driver, who has a child with him, fired at least one shot in the air and parked his car near a plane that has since been evacuated, officials said.
content: All flights in and out of the Hamburg Airport in Germany were canceled until further notice as the authorities responded Saturday night to an armed man who drove his vehicle onto the tarmac and parked near a plane.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Terreri Ramos
title: Is an In-Home Elevator a Wise Investment for Seniors?
description: Demand will only increase for housing that allows people to age in place, especially in cities with larger senior populations.
content: Q: My husband and I live in Portland, Ore., in a three-level single-family home. Three bedrooms and two bathrooms are on the top level, and we are constantly up and down stairs and use all of the rooms in the house. We are in our late 70s and we’re thinking of installing an in-home elevator to enable us to stay in the house as we age. (Our friends who have done this say elevators are better than stair adaptations, because they can accommodate a wheelchair.) But will installing an elevator for seniors devalue the property and cost too much to maintain?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles Homans and Rachel Woolf
title: Lauren Boebert Wants ‘Mercy.’ Some Republicans Want an Alternative.
description: The “Beetlejuice” incident continues to haunt the once-unrepentant congresswoman from Colorado. The state’s old guard is lining up behind a primary challenger.
content: At a casino bingo hall in southwestern Colorado, Lauren Boebert, the Republican congresswoman, bounced her 6-month-old grandson on her knee.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Damon Linker
title: Get to Know the Influential Conservative Intellectuals Who Help Explain G.O.P. Extremism
description: A coalition of catastrophists is trying to make the next generation of Republicans believe that the country is on the verge of collapse.
content: It’s easy to become inured to the extremism that has suffused the Republican Party in recent years. Donald Trump, the dominating front-runner for the party’s presidential nomination, spends days in court, in a judicial system he regularly disparages, charged with a long list of offenses and facing several trials.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Esther Zuckerman
title: Are ‘Elf’ and ‘Love Actually’ the Last Holiday Classics We’ll Ever Get?
description: The two comedies opened on the same date in 2003 and have stood the test of time. A changing Hollywood landscape might make another such day impossible.
content: On Nov. 7, 2003, American audiences had the opportunity to see either “Elf” or “Love Actually” for the very first time in theaters. They could find themselves humming “Baby, It’s Cold Outside” along with Will Ferrell or sobbing to “Both Sides Now” with Emma Thompson. They could imagine themselves running through Central Park to save Santa or dashing through Heathrow to catch their beloved before a flight. And chances are, many of the moviegoers who watched those films on that fateful day in November have revisited them since. After all, both have become bona fide seasonal classics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Talya Minsberg and Rosem Morton
title: How the New York City Marathon Is Supporting New Moms on Race Day
description: Returning to competition after childbirth can be challenging, but new accommodations for runners, like lactation tents, can ease the transition.
content: For most of her life, Molly Huddle had a fairly simple routine before the start of a race.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kathryn Shattuck
title: What Fuels the ‘Manic Creativity’ of Joan Baez
description: The 82-year-old singer and subject of a new documentary sleeps in a tree, has come to terms with not being a reader and is more interested in upside down than right side up.
content: About seven years ago, Joan Baez — singer, activist, icon — decided she was ready.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Will Heinrich
title: Performa Keeps It Live and Real in the Age of TikTok
description: Since 2005, Performa — New York’s only performance biennial — has been building in-person human connections, an experience that’s increasingly rare.
content: It’s 2023. Using only your smartphone you can study dance moves in Berlin, shout along with protests in Iran, watch opera in Finland or witness catastrophe in the Middle East, if not live then close to it. In other words, it’s easier than it’s ever been to believe you’re everywhere when you’re actually nowhere, to feel as if you’re acting when you’re only reacting, to think you’re making connections when you’re totally alone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Audio
title: Listen Early to ‘This American Life’: Is That What I Look Like?
description: Why it often takes an outsider to set yourself straight.
content: You’ve been seeing yourself, getting to know what you look like, your whole life. So why does it often take an outsider to see things about you that are obvious, and set you straight?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Colbi Edmonds and Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
title: Maine Gunman Was Most Likely Alive for Much of 2-Day Manhunt
description: The assailant in the mass shooting in Lewiston died about eight to 12 hours before his body was found, officials say.
content: The gunman who fled after killing 18 people and injuring 13 others at a bar and a bowling alley in Lewiston, Maine, last month was most likely alive during much of the sprawling two-day manhunt that had forced thousands of residents throughout the region to remain in their homes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Goldberg
title: When It Comes to Israel, Who Decides What You Can and Can’t Say?
description: Why both sides feel victimized by the campus debate over the war in Gaza.
content: Last week, the Anti-Defamation League and the Louis D. Brandeis Center for Human Rights Under Law sent a letter to nearly 200 college presidents urging them to investigate campus chapters of Students for Justice in Palestine for potential violations of federal and state laws against providing material support to terrorism. As evidence for these very serious accusations, the ADL and the Brandeis center offered only the student group’s own strident rhetoric, including a sentence in its online tool kit, which praised Hamas’s attacks on Israel and said: “We must act as part of this movement. All of our efforts continue the work and resistance of the Palestinians on the ground.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Grose
title: The Despair at the Heart of Britney Spears’s Memoir
description: A thread of mismanaged postpartum depression and grief — and how it destroyed generations of her family — runs through the book.
content: The first chapter of Britney Spears’s new memoir, “The Woman in Me,” includes the story of her paternal grandmother, Emma Jean Spears, called Jean; everybody says Britney Spears looks like her, but that’s not the only thing they have in common.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Do Today’s Students Lack Ethics?
description: Readers react to an essay by Ezekiel J. Emanuel lamenting that some students have “moral blinders.”
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Talya Minsberg
title: How Chefs Eat With the Marathon in Mind
description: Marathons require a lot of dietary discipline. So what happens when running is your passion and food is your job?
content: Soon after Dave Beran finished the New York City Marathon in 2014, he made his way to one of the fanciest restaurants in Manhattan, Per Se.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Fleit
title: The Hard-Partying College Kids Who Were Also Drug Lords
description: Max Marshall’s “Among the Bros” investigates a multimillion-dollar crime network among fraternity brothers at the College of Charleston.
content: “It’s almost a sign of prestige,” an anonymous college student tells the journalist Max Marshall in “Among the Bros”: “While everyone is refining their lives to get ready for the professional world,” he and his fraternity brothers “can go hard.” No matter what harm they cause in the process, he knows he is so well connected that “I am still going to be taken care of.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Missy Elliott, Willie Nelson and Sheryl Crow Join the Rock Hall
description: Innovators from genres that have long been underrepresented in the Rock & Roll Hall of Fame were celebrated at the event’s 38th annual induction ceremony in Brooklyn.
content: The Rock & Roll Hall of Fame inducted its 38th annual class of musical heroes on Friday at Barclays Center in Brooklyn, in a night dominated by strong women and giants from genres the institution had long treated as adjacent to rock.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karen Loew
title: We’re All ‘Citizens’ in the Republic of Branding
description: If we don’t feel connected to our neighbors, maybe can we buy belonging one latte at a time?
content: Naming a business comes with different motivations: immortalizing a family name; appealing to whimsy; a straightforward declaration of the items sold. What’s more unusual is for you, the consumer, to be directly addressed by the company name.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kayla Guo
title: Rashida Tlaib Posts Video Accusing Biden of Supporting ‘Genocide’
description: Representative Tlaib has been on the leading edge of a group of Democrats critical of the president’s embrace of Israel, but the accusation marks an extraordinary broadside from a lawmaker of his own party.
content: Representative Rashida Tlaib, Democrat of Michigan and an outspoken voice for a cease-fire in the Israel-Hamas war, released a video on Friday that accused President Biden of supporting the genocide of Palestinians.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times Cooking
title: Jammy Tomato Eggs for a Bolstering Breakfast
description: And some low-key weekend cooking projects: easy tomato sauce, beef Bourguignon and sunny yellow limoncello.
content: Is there anything more luxurious than a hot breakfast, leisurely prepared while in pajamas on a chilly weekend with coffee in hand? (Possibly, but for the sake of this particular New York Times Cooking newsletter, no.) And is there anything more comforting than a treasured family dish that transports you home with the first spoonful? (To this we can confidently say: nope.) Yewande Komolafe’s jammy tomato breakfast eggs are a one-two punch of breakfast richness and nostalgia. Her mother would prepare the dish when visiting from Nigeria; “The scent of her dried herb seasoning blend, mixed and packed right before her trip, would hang in the air as she cooked,” Yewande writes. Runny-yolked eggs tucked into a thick blanket of red peppers, tomatoes and chile, showered with spices — a luscious, lovely breakfast.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christoph Koettl, Ainara Tiefenthäler, Haley Willis and Alexander Cardia
title: Israel Used 2,000-Pound Bombs in Strike on Jabaliya, Analysis Shows
description: Impact craters from the Oct. 31 strike on the densely packed Gaza neighborhood are approximately 40 feet wide. Israel said it was aiming at underground Hamas targets.
content: Israel used at least two 2,000-pound bombs during an airstrike on Tuesday on Jabaliya, a dense area just north of Gaza City, according to experts and an analysis conducted by The New York Times of satellite images, photos and videos.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Ballot-Stuffers Caught on Camera Have Upended a Race for Mayor
description: In Bridgeport, Conn., a judge found evidence of mishandled ballots in the Democratic primary for mayor and ordered a revote. But first, the city will hold a general election. After that? Stay tuned.
content: Residents of Bridgeport, Conn., are preparing to cast their ballots in what may be the most confusing election in the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lysley Tenorio
title: One Man’s Complicated Quest for Connection in Contemporary Tehran
description: Salar Abdoh’s latest novel, “A Nearby Country Called Love,” explores the complexities of relationships, sexuality and cultural norms in modern Iran.
content: A NEARBY COUNTRY CALLED LOVE, by Salar Abdoh
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erin Brethauer and Tim Hussin and Mark Arax
title: What Happened When California Chose to Rebuild a Town Devastated by Wildfire
description: The rebuilding of Paradise, Calif., feels like a test of human fortitude.
content: Before the fire that destroyed almost everything here, Paradise was one of those blunders of American suburbia, a misplaced place that made little ecological sense. It inhabited a California landscape that wasn’t quite rolling foothill or rugged Sierra but an in-between zone where Ponderosa pines, Douglas firs and incense cedars kept the earth from baking like the great valley below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Kenigsberg
title: Here Are the Most Anticipated Films of the Holiday Season
description: “The Color Purple” and “Poor Things” and Beyoncé lead a list packed with goodies. Mark your calendars.
content: The leaves are falling, and at least one of the strikes looming over the film season has been resolved. From Wiseman to Wonka, Beyoncé to Ferrari, here is a select list of the films you need to know about this winter. Release dates and platforms are subject to change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Gold and Nicholas Nehamas
title: DeSantis and Trump Bring Their Campaign Battle Home to Florida
description: At a state party summit, Gov. Ron DeSantis and former President Donald J. Trump both argued that Florida was their turf. For the crowd, Mr. Trump’s assertion seemed to ring truer.
content: When Gov. Ron DeSantis took the stage at a state Republican Party event in Kissimmee, Fla., on Saturday, he strode in front of a giant screen that proclaimed “Florida Is DeSantis Country.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Entous and Thomas Fuller
title: Blinken Meets Arab Ministers in Bid to Calm Outrage Over Gaza Airstrikes
description: A missile attack on an ambulance convoy has drawn severe criticism, including from the U.N., but Israel says it was transporting Hamas fighters.
content: Anxious Arab leaders appealed publicly and privately on Saturday to Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken to rein in Israel’s military campaign in the Gaza Strip, increasing pressure on the Biden administration as it struggles to persuade Israel to reduce civilian casualties and allow in more humanitarian aid.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer and Constant Méheut
title: Zelensky Rebuke of Top General Signals Rift in Ukrainian Leadership
description: The presidential office said Gen. Valery Zaluzhny’s declaration that the war is at a stalemate was helpful to the Russians.
content: The office of President Volodymyr Zelensky on Saturday chastised Ukraine’s top military commander for publicly declaring the war at a stalemate, suggesting the comments would help the Russian invasion. It was a striking public rebuke that signaled an emerging rift between the military and civilian leadership at an already challenging time for Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erik Ofgang
title: What Happens to Illustrators When Robots Can Draw Robots?
description: Illustrators have made a living creating book covers. Now, artificial intelligence is learning to make art.
content: The first time Michael Whelan was warned that robots were coming for his job was in the 1980s. He had just finished painting the cover for a mass-market paperback edition of Stephen King’s “The Dark Tower: The Gunslinger,” a gritty portrait of the title character with the outline of a tower glimpsed through the haze behind him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyson Krueger
title: Many Despise the End of Daylight Saving Time. Some Can’t Wait.
description: “It’s like a gift and I have to make the most of it.”
content: “The measurement of time,” said Alex Reifsnyder, “is something that doesn’t really get altered any time throughout the year except for these two days.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Streitfeld
title: Look, Up in the Sky! It’s a Can of Soup!
description: Amazon’s much-hyped drone project is dropping small objects on driveways. Some customers are not sure what it delivers beyond minestrone.
content: Exactly a decade ago, Amazon revealed a program that aimed to revolutionize shopping and shipping. Drones launched from a central hub would waft through the skies delivering just about everything anyone could need. They would be fast, innovative, ubiquitous — all the Amazon hallmarks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin
title: For a Chair-Throwing Basketball Coach, Baseball Was a Comforting Coda
description: As his memory declined, Bobby Knight, the volatile former Indiana University basketball coach, found some solace in the Cleveland baseball team of his youth.
content: Luke Epplin answered a phone call two years ago. He didn’t recognize the Indiana number, but the voice on the other end of the line was unmistakable.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Taub, Emily Schmall, Shalini Venugopal Bhagat and Andrea Bruce
title: Chapter 3: Bargaining for Time
description: She had dreams of a prestigious government career. Her family wanted an engagement she couldn’t refuse.
content: Arti Kumari, 22, crouched on a dusty dirt track in a runner’s lunge, waiting to spring forward as soon as her mother started the clock.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Run-Down
description: David P. Williams’s new construction might give you déjà vu.
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE — This is David P. Williams’s second crossword for The New York Times, after an August debut that also ran on a Saturday. As Mr. Williams promised, both puzzles have identical grid patterns, and this seems to be the second installment of a series inspired by Wallace Stevens’s poem “Thirteen Ways of Looking at a Blackbird.” Who doesn’t like a touch of suspense with their solve? Only one comment on the Wordplay post for the August grid mentioned a Stevens reference, but it didn’t elucidate, and I don’t see a connection between the poem and either puzzle. It might be hidden in the geometry of the puzzle itself, since that’s a constant, or in the crosshatch of entries in its center. If anyone finds bread crumbs, please share them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Sperling
title: Actors’ Union Says It Receives ‘Last, Best and Final’ Offer From Studios
description: SAG-AFTRA, which has been on strike for 114 days, did not give a timeline for when it would respond.
content: The negotiating committee of the actors’ union, SAG-AFTRA, told its members on Saturday that it had received a “Last, Best and Final Offer” from the major entertainment studios as a strike that has brought much of Hollywood to a standstill continued for a 114th day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Blumenfeld, Carmit Hoomash, Alexandra Eaton and Arijeta Lajka
title: ‘I Knew He Was Looking for Me’: Video Shows How Oct. 7 Attack on Kibbutz Sufa Unfolded
description: A Hamas body camera captured the Oct. 7 attack on Kibbutz Sufa, and the Israeli military later released sections of the footage as evidence of a strategic attack on civilians. Along with security camera footage obtained by The New York Times and witness testimony from survivors, the videos help document how events unfolded that morning.
content: A Hamas body camera captured the Oct. 7 attack on Kibbutz Sufa, and the Israeli military later released sections of the footage as evidence of a strategic attack on civilians. Along with security camera footage obtained by The New York Times and witness testimony from survivors, the videos help document how events unfolded that morning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Blinken Says Cease-Fire in Gaza Would Allow Hamas to Regroup
description: Antony J. Blinken, the secretary of state, rebuffed calls from his counterparts in Egypt and Jordan for an immediate cease-fire in Gaza, saying that a halt would allow Hamas to repeat its attack on Israel.
content: Antony J. Blinken, the secretary of state, rebuffed calls from his counterparts in Egypt and Jordan for an immediate cease-fire in Gaza, saying that a halt would allow Hamas to repeat its attack on Israel.
source.name: The New York Times
